posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
calling it now, 7000 x3d chips are going to be a massive disappointment.
7800x3d might be a decent value option if priced competitively with 13700k but it will still be worse than 13900k overall while being worthless for non-gaming tasks (including emulation)
7900x3d will be a joke with only 6 cores per ccd. Inferior to the regular 7900x for multithread, inferior to 7800x3d for gaming. A cpu for no one. Scheduling is also guaranteed to be a shitshow.
7950x3d will be in a similar boat to the 7900 but probably comparable in gaming performance to to the 7800x3d while being only marginally worse in multithread than the regular 7950. Also it will be like $700. Basically it’ll be a nice bonus for professionals who need a 7950 for their work but also want to game on the side. Will still lose to the 13900k overall though.

>>90906564
looking at koboldai in terminal i can actually maybe answer why the memory issue happens in cai. keep in mind i'm not an ai expert.

every time you make a request to the model, it sends (in one big text block) the entire character definitions and example chats, as well as as much of the recent chat as it can possibly fit, up to a limit, because the model/gpu can only handle a large enough prompt. keep in mind that every time you send a message to any of these chatbot services, this is what it's doing - passing the entire history to the model. therefore, if you have a long enough chat, the oldest messages are going to get cut off and the next message it generates won't have access to it.

which also brings up another issue, i noticed that tavern seems to actually chop off the character definitions if you have a long enough conversation, rather than keeping the character definitions and chopping off conversation instead. this would likely be why it "forgets" it's personality after a while

posts.com:
Users of all levels are welcome.
Share Windows tools, utilities, tips & tricks.

FAQ:
>How do I activate Windows?
https://github.com/massgravel/Microsoft-Activation-Scripts
HWID mimics upgrade activation to generate a permanent legitimate license. (works on non-VL editions only)

>>Which version should I install?
>Home/Pro
Comes with bloatware apps (games, music, news, etc) and bloatware system apps
>Education/Workstation/Enterprise
Comes with bloatware system apps (weather, people, onedrive, teams, etc).
>LTSC (5 years support, VL/KMS only) / IoT LTSC (10 years support, HWID only)
Comes with Win32 system utils, no MS Store, no apps.
If you need MS Store, run this in cmd: wsreset -i
Install Xbox/Gamebar apps for feature parity with other W10 editions.

>Do I even need IoT LTSC?
W10 Home/Pro/Edu/WS/Ent editions end support in 2025, LTSC in 2027, IoT LTSC in 2032.

>How do I activate Office?
https://github.com/abbodi1406/KMS_VL_ALL_AIO/releases
Emulates a KMS server, not ideal as KMS trips AV sometimes and deactivates. Alternatively, use MSOffice through your browser since it's free.
Or you can try OnlyOffice/LibreOffice/WPS and set it to save as MSOffice file formats.

>Where can I get Windows/Office ISOs?
https://massgrave.dev/genuine-installation-media.html
Other sources:
https://pastebin.com/p6b3N9w2

>Is Optimize-Offline worth it?
>Should I debloat?
If you need to ask, then no. You WILL break something.
If you know what you're doing:
https://pastebin.com/S5VKBirt

https://pastebin.com/hN8nnwns

https://www.4chan-x.net

OpenShell/RetroBar/WinClassic/StartIsBack

No.

the dishwasher doesn't just magically remove all material off of the surface of the pan unless you use some seriously toxic stuff (acids). And even then it's not a good idea as you also strip the outercoating if it's been cured.
Which means that if it's cast iron, it's going to rust.

The cheapest, easiest solution, and sometimes fastest is to have someone pre-scrub most heavy stuff before putting it into the dishwasher, or if you put it through at all.

It's the same for plates, if they've got cheese or something, I used to guess that about 50% of them still have cheese on them when they come out without some light scrubbing. If you have hundreds of plates of different types, and 300 customers, the cook staff are going to be short on stuff and be less efficient looking for shit, thus affecting how quickly food is delivered to the customer.
3 different restaurants all had the some quirks and same shit. My guess it's likely the same in most places.

>>90900369
>more confusing
Sounds like you got filtered.
>avx512
There are crates for doing this. Actually, the llml_simd crate can use avx512 while on x86_64 CPUs that support it, while using the neon instructions on ARM/AArch64 CPUs that support that. So instead of targeting a specific platform, you can use an abstraction over simd and get platform-specific instructions that are going to benefit from the increased performance.

>>90902881
Rust is a language that makes a lot more sense when you've got a number of years of experience using systems languages. It especially makes sense if you already use C++. If you're the type of person who only uses C, you'll be a bit confused by some of Rust's abstractions. For example, consider the guy confused about multiple types of strings...

>>90902962
Not all strings are equal. For instance: should we use the same type for strings that are UTF-16 encoded and strings that are UTF-8 encoded? If we do, then we need to store at runtime what encoding we're using. Or we could only accept one encoding, but then we run into troubles when it turns out that different OS APIs use different encodings. Maybe we should have one type that abstracts the idea of "this is for communicating with OS APIs and we don't care what encoding it is", and one type for "this is for general use and we're going go use the same encoding on all platforms".

Okay, great, but we have other questions now. Should all strings be stored on the heap? What about strings that are embedded in the binary, like string literals? Heap strings need to be freed, but string literals are read only. What if we had one interface for managing a heap owned string, and one interface for manipulating strings without concern for where they are in memory.

So that's how you get OsStr, OsString, Str, and String. Also, CStr and CString exist precisely because C got strings wrong in the first place, but we still need to interact with C libraries.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90908043

macro_rules! print {
    ($($arg:tt)*) => {{
        $crate::io::_print($crate::format_args!($($arg)*));
    }};
}

macro_rules! println {
    () => {
        $crate::print!("\n")
    };
    ($($arg:tt)*) => {{
        $crate::io::_print($crate::format_args_nl!($($arg)*));
    }};
}


Is the gist of it. The real question you should be asking is how the format_args macro is implemented. And the answer to that is... it's a compiler built-in! Although it probably doesn't really need to be given the improvements Rust has had in the capabilities of macros, I can only guess that it's a performance optimization. What that format_args macro is going to do though is turn everything into a core::fmt::Arguments struct... which is internal to the standard library, and constructing one on your own without the macro is not considered stable. Once you have that Arguments struct though, you're basically just punting it over to the write_fmt function on the StdoutLock object.

>>90882406
This isn't a class component. When using function components there is rarely a need for using "this" and this.state will very likely not be defined.
useState returns an array [currentState, setThisStateFunction].
If you want to access the state use the returned currentState value (in this case named tabActive).
I am a bit confused why you want to access state with this.state.tabActive, you already successfully used it in you if condition, just tabActive.
To set the state to a different value, call setTabActive(newValue)
You should probably read https://beta.reactjs.org/

security bros: i went down an autistic rabbit hole today re: password hashing and came to the conclusion that bcrypt is superior despite its 72-byte truncation, until argon2id becomes the php default and therefore superior (it should have happened in php 7.2-7.3 but internals are pussies)

am i wrong? the prior scheme was using a hardcoded sha512 algo with null byte stripping to enable the use of arbitrary long passwords, which seems good in theory

then i ran some shannon entropy calculators on the outputs and discovered that if your password is 72 bytes of random data (the best possible under bcrypt), string-escaping it reduces the entropy, but so does sha512'ing it

it's also a lot harder/impossible to upgrade the pre-hash algo without forcing a sitewide password reset. ran into that problem trying to upgrade the pre-hash to sha3-512

am i right to believe that bcrypt even with its truncation, and the ability to seamlessly upgrade algos in the future, is better than using an already-outdated hash (sha2) that may be the next md5 re: shucking vulns?

Mostly it is fine with one server.
But if you want a global system then.

Setup your servers across the globe.
Use Docker Swarm: see this for an easy install https://dockerswarm.rocks/
Add those machines to the same swarm and when you push an update it will automatically update all of the machines.
Or use Kubernetes, but that is more tricky to setup, not that hard nowadays, but harder.

Use Cloudflare or any of the big cloud providers will be able to route traffic based on which server has the lowest ping.
https://developers.cloudflare.com/load-balancing/understand-basics/traffic-steering/steering-policies/proximity-steering/

>>90894369
Normally you'd use 406 to indicate that the sever can't produce a representation of the requested resource that is acceptable to the client. For instance, the client might have declared that it prefers content in French (via Accept-Language) but it's only available in English and for whatever reason the server doesn't default to it. Then 406 would be appropriate.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Ok here's my take.
What the shell needs to do is start processes, and you need to manage those.
Everything related to processed happens concurrently and asynchronously by nature, starting/stopping a process, signals, IPC, and the shell needs to have all the primitives to control them.

Although the shell's name is a pun and was intented to make us thing about the synergy shell/kernel and hints at the system call interface, the shell doesn't need to being able to make all system calls, it just needs to be able to start/stop processes, send send signals, make them communicate, filesystem operations (cd, ls, pwd, stat, chmod, chown, etc..) that's it. Making use of all the other system calls is the role of a real programming language, wether "system"/compiled or scripting language.

Often you do not lauch processes to have side effects but to obtain data from them, and you want to be able to process that data.
Making 2 "real programs" communicate is something that should be easy to do,
BUT,
making the data processing happen with fork/exec/wait/pipe and using separate executables to do trivial things like string filtering (grep), is really fucking stupid. There is absolutely no reason to do it this way. It's inefficient and it's not even good.
1/

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90900448
The shell should have all the usual operations that you'd have in a scripting language builting (simple variables, arrays, hash tables, number and string operations, regexes (one embeded regex engine for all regex operations just like perl and scripting langauges do), list operations (filter/grep, map, sort, uniq, etc..), and also control flow (good this time). Also, it should be easy to compose everything and not have stupid quotation and wordsplitting rules in your way.

If you don't have that you end up using perl just like I do.
Basically I'm arguing for a scripting langage with a lightweight syntax adapted to launch little commands.

I am convinced that it should have been like that if in an impossible reality we had scripting languages before shells, because clearly Ken Thomspon and Bourne couldn't into functional-like/expressive languages.
I've got the impression that it's what PowerShell is about anyway.

>>90903031
if grep, sed, awk, etc or something equivalent was buitltin, the entire stream could be optimized away, like no need to pass 1 line into 3 pipes and process consecutively, but instead have ony 1 loop representing the entire stream
grep something becomes
if ( ! match(line, somehting)) {
    continue;
}

sed s/pat/text/g becomes
substitute(&line, "pat", "text", "g");

each of those conditionals are one after the other inside the body of the loop
if you do this, it would be extremely cache friendly and would proabbly be an order of magnitude faster if not more

You tell the controller: "I don't need these blocks anymore. If you want to write something there, go ahead." The data's still there but the space is FREE to store new files on, old data is just ignored.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90893686
You need the new fan, some thermal paste and a screwdriver. Also something to wipe it off with and alcohol. That's it.
Remove the old paste with cotton pads or toilet paper and dab some isopropyl or rubbing alcohol on it beforehand. You can also use cotton swabs if the old paste doesn't go off easily. Just remember to use the alcohol.

What you should pay attention to is not breaking any ribbon cables or connectors. Also make sure to use the right amount of paste and screw the cooler back on evenly so it spreads nicely.
Doing a shit job applying the thermal paste is no problem as you can just redo it. Breaking connectors or cables is utter bullshit which will cost you. Don't forget to power the computer off properly and remove the battery before starting.

If it doesn't turn on after reassembly don't panic. Some laptops need to detect the battery or fan first before powering up after a disassembly. Check wether you connected all necessary cables and connect a charger. Then just spam the power button. Good luck!

>>90902477

>>90906830
Flatpaks are basically like installing an entire Linux distro for each program you run (Flatpak Runtimes)

If someone wants to distribute a malicious program, there is now thousands of potential files to hide it in, every library of the entire Flatpak Runtime

This is mostly stopped by the fact that maintainers only write a "recipe" and that "recipe" gets built by Flathub.

The "recipe" is supposed to be approved by Flathub moderators, but after that the person is free to update it basically unsuperivised.

Ultimately on Linux, you are trusting the package maintainers with everything. They are the weakest link.

If an Arch package maintainer or Flatpak maintainer wants to make a malicious package, they can and depending on how they do it not get caught.

The vast majority of packages in Arch repos are at least reproducible, preventing this ( https://reproducible.archlinux.org/ )

Several different parities compile a package and it all has have the same checksum

Some software inherently is going to come up different even if you compile it twice on the same exact system though

;; a comment macro for elisp (like clojure)
;; >>87116763
;; https://clojuredocs.org/clojure.core/comment
(defmacro comment (&rest body) nil)

;; https://www.emacswiki.org/emacs/ThreadMacroFromClojure
(defmacro -> (&rest body)
  (let ((result (pop body)))
    (dolist (form body result)
      (setq result (append (list (car form) result)
                           (cdr form))))))

(defmacro ->> (&rest body)
  (let ((result (pop body)))
    (dolist (form body result)
      (setq result (append form (list result))))))

>>90905561
Yeah, so the idea is to reimplement a modern web browser from the ground up in a single extensible layer using lisp. Obviously you're sol if you want to use the normal stack(though it MAY be possible to do some wizardry, I'm not hopeful for a magical open source html rendering engine anytime soon), so instead you use something else, probably sexps, maybe byte compile and compressed. Now you've basically reinvented HTML+CSS+JS. Did you do a better job? Maybe. And then you've got to network all this, and it's obviously going to have to be p2p since lets face it, it'll never be popular enough for a server ecosystem to make sense. Best way to do that is a DHT, maybe a skipgraph, you've now reinvented DNS, but much slower and more complicated since it needs to run on normal machines and not optically accelerated ASICs.
Lets say you finish it, you've got your perfect networked searchable all lisp ecosystem you can hook into from any computer anywhere in the world. How do you run programs not written in lisp? Now you've got to make untold amounts of libraries, hooks, boilerplate, etc... all in multiple other languages across lots of architectures just to attempt running the stuff.

Meanwhile, WASM already runs in browsers, it's based on sexps, operates off the normal internet, runs on all platforms, and works as a compilation target for all existing languages so old software can be directly compiled into WASM and run both in the browser and directly on bare metal. All the work has already been done, you can go try it out right now.

Obviously the answer is to take WASM and use it to build your lisp ecosystem idea, but currently it doesn't have GC or memory management, so everyone's stuck in limbo waiting for the ability for the ability of modules to create and execute other modules. Once that gets going it's just a matter of implementing a simple framework and you've got a single page operating system.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90907912
Not platform interop, PROGRAM interop. If OTHER programs can also be compiled into wasm you can use the wasm interface to do cross machine IPC. Basically, because it all runs on the same virtual machine, you can ship the memory state around and reuse it without doing any translation, just like CL images. So you can run autocad in wasm on your machine, then pause the system, zip the vm state, send it to another computer, and continue from where you left off.
Or, if you implement an entire os in wasm, you could hibernate your entire system into a file, and using those augmented hyperlinks I mentioned before, remotely back it up, open and run it, dissassemble and step through it, etc...
The reason you want to actually use wasm instead of just compiling to it or compiling to x86 is in order to use these high level features your program has to KNOW it's running in wasm and how wasm modules/memories work and how to run them.

>>90907979
Really that's just showing the superiority of interpreters and the tyranny of compiled assembly. If I'm running 15 layered javascript operating systems and using 15 GB of memory and 1kw of power to run a webshit calculator, the performance gains of compilers are moot. Who fucking cares if it takes 1000 times as long to crunch numbers if my computer is 10,000,000 times faster?
Sure, don't try to do graphics with an interpreter, BUT THE CPU DOESN'T DO THAT ANYWAY! The commands get COMPILED TO SHADER CODE! So all the graphics and numbercrunching shit can just be compiled for the GPU, and all general purpose CPU bound code can be interpreted!
Boom, 90% of all programs are now irrelevant and obsolete!
>don't need compilers
>don't need process control since you can cram entire vm images into continuations
>don't need multithreading libraries, just run one interpreter per core, all the images are single threaded
>don't need containerization, ALL PROCESSES are containers
>don't need access control, if you've got the link for data you have access, if you don't you can't reach it since it doesn't even exist as far as you're concerned
>don't need a browser, all your os level programs are trivially networked and distributed, you can replace a website with a program image and automatically download it, run it in a sandboxed container, and have it access server side data itself
>don't need suspend, hibernate, shutdown, restart, etc... since your entire system state is just a file

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
eh, it's not hat difficult, except SDKs are mostly utter garbage and every example project is useless and buggy

maybe I'm in a vendor bubble, but are 32-bit ARMs dominant nowadays? everyone I know develops around Cortex-M series from STMicroelectronics or Texas Instruments.
If so then ST's Nucleo kits are pretty nice. And overall ST's docs are ok (but their website sucks balls)

I don't know how can people stand the Eclipse-based IDEs. ST bought Atollic and rebranded it as their CubeIDE. It's old version of eclipse without CMake or Meson support. Making reusable libraries in it was annoying since you could not way what things are compiled or any provide options, had to be done in every user project.
The company I worked in until recently were building with the Eclipse projects, and it kind of sucked. Was also a pain in Gitlab CI since the image needed the full IDE to build the thing, which was maybe 1 GB image.
But at least it helps you set up the compiler flags and linker scripts. And the debugger scripts and register views.
But if you do the work yourself, you can make sane CMake build scripts for anything, and even integrate the debugger and flashing tools to VS Code and remote debug with it. It can be a lot of work though.

What is linting and unit testing? I'm a web developer

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90908042
>linting
A programs scans your code before compiling to see if anything strange is happening (unused variables, unclear math that makes the compiler guess the intended equation, pointers to weird memory locations, etc)
>unit testing
A unit is scanned through a JTAG port to look for missing solder connections under the IC. You could also do it by hand, or with xrays. Also verify the ROM in case a bit flipped or something.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90907957
1) It's true I don't have a ton of experience with networking. That said, I am very aware these are different flavors of the same thing. I have worked a lot with zmq and redis, but there are some real annoyances with using them(redis is bloated and single threaded, written in a language I don't care for, while zmq has bizzarre quirks like not being able to set a timeout on a poll request without having to fire some kind of notify event to release the socket in the form of some dummy message that tells it to quit waiting which is janky and annoying and eats cpu cycles pointlessly doing networking it doesn't need to do) That's precisely why I came to 4chan to ask about alternatives. I think memchached may be decent for a caching server for the unencrpyted data on the backend, but I am still unsure it's the best and I don't know what to use for the actually light weight coms protocol.

2) I want to be able to send packets over my network and other networks using existing hardware. This means I will need something cross platform that manage to do UDP connections at the bare minimum. A nice feature of zmq is it can also do stuff like pub-sub so you can have many to one connections. I find needing many to many connections is unlikely for my use cases though as I am not trying to build a distributed system(at least not a decentralized one, as I scale up I plan to have a few load balancing relays to pass the data to a backend if needed once I get to a size where that matter, if it ever matters. as far as your comment about a clothes stack, sure I'll humour you. I have 14 slightly different colored t shirts, 14 khaki pants, a vest, and a jacket. I wear these all day, every day, and I put the jacket on whenever I leave my house/work(yes, regardless of weather, the pockets are handy) It's a waste of my time to spend time thinking about what I am going to wear. If it is below freezing I may throw a coat on over my jacket... but I usually don't.

>USB-A ports
This is what Apple does and has always done. They cut out legacy shit and force the world to adapt to modern tech. The same happened when they removed the DVD drive from the MacBook Air and the entire world was screeching at them. A few years later the industry finally got to the point where a disc drive had no logical sense.

The same is happening with USB C now. Companies suddenly start adapting their accessories en masse. It will be annoying for a bit but that’s massively better than chugging along with dumb old standards for 20 years just because “it would be annoying for 2-3 years”. It’s exactly why Excel still counts leap years wrong, because that’s how Lotus Notes did it.

>>90895213
I buy only mystery ranch as you can see.

My work daily driver is the 3 way. It's perhaps a bit fat but it's well made and thought of. I have had it carry three laptops but usually with me is my work macbook pro, a lot of cables for different things, a gozero sherpa powerbank with 60W of type c power output, a mouse and whatever shit I might need. It can expand by opening up a zipper that compresses it so I can put in a jacket if I need to but I try to keep it just for the computer and accessories, everything I need and might need. it has backpack straps too that hide in the back. Useful if it turns out I have to carry it for a longer time.

The 2 day assault is my daily driver backpack when I'm bringing my personal PC and camera with me. It's very EDC focused so it has a good padded laptop pocket with easy access and a lot of other storage options. I wish it had a larger capacity but for what it is, and for the price, it's a winner. It hardly shows any signs of wear even though I've used it a lot.

The largest is the Komodo Dragon and it's great for when I'm travelling. It's more mil gear so it doesn't have a laptop pocket but I don't tend to use this backpack when I travel with a laptop. It can carry it, but this is more like a do-it-all for hiking and stuff. I like to use this when riding with my motorcycle as I often need the capacity. As for quality compared to the 2 day assault, there is not much difference. It's stronger and bigger but how well the 2 day performs, it's hard to justify buying this. But then again, I buy it once and for life, this thing isn't going to go bad before I do.

If you are someone like >>90895213 just do yourself a service and don't buy this shit, it'll just break and wear down and you'll be buying the same shit over and over and you can never trust it to not fail. That's the biggest difference to me, I can 100% rely on my gear.

Mystery Ranch ain't the only company making good backpacks, but they are good.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90894027
Usually it's called "direct lit" for an array of LEDs backlit that dim equally across the panel, and FALD (Full array local dimming) for an array of LEDs that have independent dimming zones (so the bottom corner can be fully off but the top opposite corner is full brightness)


There is also edge lit where all the LEDs are at the edges of the panel, this is the cheapest and worst.

If yours is "direct lit" and not FALD, then it's better than edge lit, but still not going to provide an amazing experience in the dark since the entire panel is dimming not smaller individual pixel zones.

>>90894838
Yes, but there is still concern with OLED and burn-in, so you need to make sure to keep it off when not in use, and not leave static content (singular frames) for extended periods of time.

You also can't play the same video game every single day for 10+ hours at a time or it'll burn-in the UI elements, like if you played WoW for example every single day, eventually you'd find the quickbars for skills/spells would burn into the display and be visible even when you're not playing the game.

But if you're varying the content OLEDs have gotten much better overall and it should easily last you years of daily use without much noticeable degradation.

But OLEDs are actually great for gaming in raw performance, sub 1ms pixel latency and 4k/120hz+.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>90893996
>there is some sort of blurry grey leakage around highly contrasted areas.
That is exactly the problem with local dimming, and not caused by wear or damage.

You are just seeing the resolution of the backlight, which is only a few hundred thousand pixels at best.
The examples all show stars because that's where the issue is the clearest: instead of seeing a star as a single bright pixel surrounded by perfect blacks you see it surrounded by a gray area the size of the local dimming area.
In scenes not involving stars the difference isn't that big, it really is an extreme case.

Imagine thinking that 1080p was sufficient as a computer monitor resolution ever. It wasn't. In the early 2000s my monitor was 1280x1024, then 1600x1200. Now it's 2560x1440 and has been since ~2010. When I had a 486 my resolution was 1024x768 and this is back in the 90s, literally DOS / Win 3.1 shit. But you have retards who in 2020+ are still settling for 1920x1080 thinking a TV broadcast resolution is ideal for a computer. LOL Now they're like "Hey bro 4K is better than 1080"...no shit.

Try 1440p because it is more than sufficient for monitors sized below 45 inches (16:9 aspect). It's all based on your viewing distance relative to screen size. A larger monitor/screen needs a higher resolution to ensure the dot pitch of the pixels remains sufficiently dense...you should not be able to see individual pixels at your normal viewing distance - if you can, you need more resolution. It's that simple. With computers, higher resolution means you can view more information on the screen in detail at the same time vs having to use virtual desktops or something like that.

posts.com:
>>90897419
>That just sounds like a cope definition for shitty contrast

No modern display take has surpassed CRT for:

- Contrast
- Motion Resolution
- Motion Smoothness

Yes, OLED can win on contrast but fails on the other two. All OLED requires some kind of interpolation and software algorithm to "transpose" motion because of the nature of how it works.

LCD sucks at all 3 of those and will never be good.

Plasma was the closest contender to surpassing CRT, but as soon as plasma tech came close to competing with CRT (Pioneer Kuro) it was shut down. Why?

DLP laser projectors (not TVs) have excellent motion and depending on your screen have pretty good contrast levels, but not enough to say they beat CRT hands-down in that regard...though most people will find that for about $3,000 you can have a 4K laser projector and quality screen which, taken as an experience, is far better than any monitor or TV for gaming and media. I will once again recommend the Optoma UHZ50, which has excellent image and motion quality along with no perceptible input lag. Input lag is the main problem with projectors; the UHZ50 has a gaming mode that addresses this.

posts.com:
>>90897576
>All these OLED monitors are coming out

Before going for an OLED, like I was going to, consider getting a laser projector. See my other post. There are two kinds; one that usually gets mounted on the ceiling about 1.5 times the distance of the width of the screen (i.e. for a screen that is 10 feet wide the projector would need to be 15 feet away from the screen). There are also "ultra-short throw" projectors, aka laser TVs, which are projectors that sit about 1.5 to 2 feet away from the screen and project upwards onto the surface. These are less flexible than traditional projectors in terms of screen size and install options, but they are convenient.

Laser projectors have MTBF of 20K hours on the light source so you can use it as a main display without worrying about having to replace a bulb. Projectors that use bulbs typically have a life of less than 2,000 hours.

>I like the cut of your jib. name the best reso and best monitor to buy.
I could suggest minimums but there isn't any best.

>I do gaming and highly detailed video editing. (hollywood / netflix post production)
For gaming on a monitor, 1440p and if you can find one in 3:2 aspect ratio you'll probably like it more than 16:9.

For video editing, more resolution benefits you for the simple fact of being able to display more information on the screen at the same time legibly. You would also need one that has true 10-bit color and support for the colorspace profile that you use. The 10-bit color thing will also need to be supported by your GPU. Since the 1000 series NVIDIA drivers have supported 10-bit color on even the consumer grade cards, at least, my 1080 Ti does 10-bit via displayport a connection...so you don't need a quadro for 10-bit color anymore. HDR for video has proven itself to be a meme so don't get caught up in the 12-bit nonsense.

My monitor is an NEC PA271W which is great for both gaming and doing actual work. It's old but still meets my needs; NEC generally makes good monitors for doing stuff like video editing or 3D modeling. If I was going to look for a replacement or upgrade, I'd start with NEC.

>>90898283
>I know some monitors you can get with REC709 colorspace. mainly the work I do is in a shotgrade(aces) or REC709(Aces) or RAW(aces).

>REC709
REC709 is nearly identical to sRGB, which fits inside Adobe RGB so any monitor that does Adobe RGB could also handle REC709 and leave you with room to grow.

>RAW
That would be converted to whatever colorspace you intend to use, so you could likely get by with a monitor that has true Adobe RGB support.

The real outlier for now is REC2020, which encompasses more color than even Adobe RGB and is for 4K+ video, often with HDR effects included.

If you game a lot, then a higher refresh rate is probably more important.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90908069
many modern games actually decouple 3D resolution from UI resolution, allowing for the 3D to run at a lower resolution to the UI and menus
also features like FSR or DLSS provide "smarter" upscaling than simple point or bilinear, which can make 1080p on a 4k display look a bit nicer than 1080p on a 1080p display, while it won't magically make the picture more detailed, it can help the picture look less aliased or pixelated

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90906248
>The future is hard to predict,
I'm not an Old yet but imo, from my limited experience, the FUTURE advances pretty fuckin' slowly. year to year is unpredictable but the obsession with "disruptive" technologies is based on a flawed assumption that a Big Thing fucks everything up and changes the whole scheme of the world every half a generation or so. This really only happened a few times in history, and even then was very gradual. even electrification took a long time to take hold and mostly involved retrofitting existing structures, and not a revolution. internet was the same, it created a way for humans to do the same things faster/easier, not in a particularly new way. digital computers replaced existing analog/human computers.

social media seems like it changed the landscape, but writers were already going on at length about similar dynamics found in small towns/villages (see stuff like "keeping up with the joneses" etc) and enabled existing behaviours (remember rolodexes?)

in fact, i challenge anyone to name even one technology that DID fundamentally change how people do things. probably the only good example is firestarting since we've evolved digestion that requires it and can ignore time of day

back to predictions, the key things to predict are what individual frameworks/brands are going to take off and looking past the hype to see what part of it is *actually* new.

even AI art bullshit has already been a thing for ages (and really doesn't matter to anyone except coomers). romance novels have been written by machine for ages, 3d artists have suites like MakeHuman and SpeedTree, etc. even chatbots have been around for like 30 years. the real "disruptive" bit of it is that these algos can be trained on more types of content and do so faster... but Google has been applying it to imagery for ages, it's what the "select all X" captchas are for.

>>90907169
they're outdated and amd users hate writing guides. with AMD the only things you need to do is get Rocm working and then install the rocm version of pytorch

follow step 1 here: (I don't even know if this is necessary but do it anyway)
https://github.com/RadeonOpenCompute/ROCm-docker/blob/master/quick-start.md

then have this in your webuser-ui.sh
export TORCH_COMMAND='pip install torch torchvision --extra-index-url https://download.pytorch.org/whl/rocm5.1.1'
later versions of rocm work too from my experience

if you already have a venv directory delete it and restart the webui

use export COMMANDLINE_ARGS=" --no-half-vae --opt-sub-quad-attention" to fix black results and reduce VRAM usage

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90890307
>A negative ion air purifier is one that causes particles in the air to gain a negative charge, which makes them bind together with positively charged particles and fall out of the air or stick to positively charged objects in the room. They are not as effective as air purifiers based on HEPA filter technology.
Assuming it actually works, it basically applies a voltage across the sides. If it's battery powered it should have a positive and negative electrode, if it's usb or plugged in it may just be positive and use earth as negative.
The idea is it charges particles and they then stick to the ground or things in your room. That way it's not in the air (probably good), but it's on other stuff and may get back into the air eventually. Not the greatest technology, but in theory it does work.

posts.com:
>>90883421
>My room is empty and barren and I would like to change that by ordering 50 kgs of chinese garbage. Does anyone have suggestions for what I should buy, I'm going for the 'chinatown souvenir shop' look. Only things in my cart right now are this and a CoD MW2 CD rug
Trinkets and souvenirs are hard to suggest. Look around for what appeals to you.
As for proper things that I got from Ali that actually made my room nicer:
- Led strips, preferably Bluetooth or WLAN compatible. It's a bit basic, but I like the look anyways. Attach to the back or underside of a desk/shelf for indirect light.
- "Fairy lights" give a comfy winter feeling. I have one around my desk and a solar one in my plants at the window. Even got one on the balcony.
- a led strip with a movement sensor under the bed so you can turn it on/off with your foot. Nice if you want to go to the toilet at night without turning the whole light on to wake up.
- comfy blankets and pillows. Pillows for bed/sofa, blanket on a chair.
- Your can get some rope hangers for plant pots for a good price if you like hanging plants.
- organizers keep clutter out of the way. I particularly like drawers that go in the PCs CD bay
- there's some pretty neat organizers for saving space in the closet for clothes
- cable organizers for clutter
- If you like the aesthetic there's sheet metal posters you can put on walls. Pictures are usually not worth it, posters may be if you like them.
- other than that it depends on your style. If you like the "hoarding weeb" aesthetic, get shelves to display figurines. If you want it more feminine, a lot of whites, pelts, lights (fairly lights are good), and wall art with fake motivational texts. Personally I quite like the "french country home" aesthetic for my kitchen (a lot of wood, metal and rustic things, generally a very open kitchen instead of clean cabinets) and a more industrial sleeping room. Both of those profit from locally buying second hand rather than AliExpress though.

>The room I have it in gets very dusty because I've a projector which does nothing but blow hot air for hours at a time
All the projector does it take dust that's already there and blow it around. And that purifier will work slowly (if at all), not nearly enough to fix a serious dust problem likely. Instead try regular cleaning of the room and ventilation. If you then still want to filter it out, get a normal filter with a fan blowing the air through it. -I am a member of HDB and what they say is correct, there's barely any HDB internal encodes anymore and there hasn't been for a couple of years, with the exception of iFT who are obviously now no longer releasing.

-Are you though? There's multiple pages of results in the past month.

-Yes, I am. There's barely any releases these days, they've dried up and it's been discussed multiple times in the forums; the consensus being that higher quality WEB-DL are rapidly released for most things, and iFT encodes despite being bloated were "good enough" for Blu-ray releases so nobody bothered to proper them except for the biggest name movies. Now without iFT there's nothing but a trickle compared to just a few years ago.
Do a search for internal encodes by year uploaded and see for yourself how few there are compared to HDB's heyday.
Edit to add that "internal" at HDB is also a meaningless term, HDB has literally hundreds of "internal" encoders because any user who encodes is free to up as internal. When people talk about "HDB internals" they don't literally mean every single uploader who ticks the internal box on the upload form, but rather the 10 or so groups based at HDB (and in some cases also at other trackers) who consistently do high-quality encodes.

Before asking for help, please check our list of resources.

If you would like to try out GNU+Linux you can do one of the following:
1) Install a GNU+Linux distribution of your choice in a Virtual Machine.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90899473
Just watch what you're doing when using pacman and actually read PKGBUILDs if you're installing stuff from the AUR and you should be ok. Do not update literally every minute like some morons tell you to. Update weekly and if you're going to install a new package and haven't done so in a while.

Do NOT check for updates by running "pacman -Syu" and canceling. This can fuck you up. Install pacman-contrib and run "checkupdates" instead.

If you're using Yay, I think it allows you to inspect PKGBUILDs by default. "yay -Pw" also is pretty handy to run before updates because if something requires manual intervention, it'll be posted on the front page of the arch website. If you don't want to use yay, subscribe to the rss feed or the mailing list.

>>90902282
>no XMPP
XMPP is not (and will probably never be) comfortable enough for majority of people to use. There are a few hundreds of different XEPs that mean nothing, as inconsistent sets of those will kill all kinds of convenience (unless you will force everyone to apply those, which is impossible). Similar thing goes for clients, as for example, your decision to use some autistically minimal client might not only affect you but other users with normal clients as well. This all taken together creates a state of eternal uncertainty, when noone knows whether things will go right or wrong.

You have to also keep in mind that people do not want to host their own servers and they never wanted to. This is why companies who offered to run software for the people were so succesfull. This is yet another reason they dont want to run their own email and xmpp (in case of email , your super private and decentralised email server does not matter if half of your recipients use gmail).

Signal and Telegram are comfy enough, however Signal is not nearly as popular as Telegram and Whatsapp. The former one is very popular among 3rd worlders, so that is the reason why so many people use it. It might happen that Telegram will become as popular as whatsapp one day or become even more popular.

READ THE WIKI! & help by contributing:
https://wiki.installgentoo.com/wiki/Home_server

>NAS Case Guide. Feel free to add to it:
https://wiki.installgentoo.com/wiki/Home_server/Case_guide

/hsg/ is about learning and expanding your horizons. Know all about NAS? Learn virtualization. Spun up some VMs? Learn about networking by standing up a OPNsense/PFsense box and configuring some VLANs. There's always more to learn and chances to grow. Think you’re god-tier already? Setup OpenStack and report back.

>What software should I run?
Install Gentoo. Or whatever flavour of *nix is best for the job or most comfy for you. Jellyfin/Plex to replace Netflix, Nextcloud to replace Googlel, Ampache/Navidrome to replace Spotify, the list goes on. Look at the awesome self-hosted list and ask.

>Why should I have a home server?
/hsg/ is about learning and expanding your horizons. De-botnet your life. Learn something new. Serving applications to yourself, your family, and your frens feels good. Put your /g/ skills to good use for yourself and those close to you. Store their data with proper availability redundancy and backups and serve it back to them with a /comfy/ easy to use interface.

posts.com:
>>90888741
port forward 3389 to your device
RDP is pretty secure (encrypted and password protected) so it should be *fine* but you would probably want to set up a VPN if you want to be even more secure.

bear in mind windows RDP does NOT use ANY hardware accelerated rendering (and there is no way to make RDP do this, either), so over longer distances and slower connections it can become unbearably slow, and I find sometimes I need to actually start loading something, close the connection and then reopen it for it to actually update the application window.
If you need to actually "use" your windows box remotely, consider a VNC solution. RDP is only really useful on local networks and for very quick or simple tasks like starting/stopping services

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90891920
they cover how to use the commands but theres probably a lot you need to learn about magnetic tape as well, like conceptually, to be able to put those commands to good use; i'm guessing you know little to nothing. but for the most part you can get by with just rewinding the tape, tar'ing a bunch of shit onto it and then again using tar to read it back. but if you want to look at individual files, compression modes, spanning across multiple tapes, etc you're going to need to learn about how data is actually stored on tape.
bear in mind noone outside of enterprises with deep pockets has used tape on a computer since never, and the difference between them and you is you can't afford the software that makes it easy; but you can learn how to do it the hard way, which involves knowing how tapes work, and mt and tar.

don't forget to store your tapes in a cool, dry place. my preferance is in food-safe, sealable tupperware containers with some silica gel in the top shelf of my kitchen pantry. it's also worth getting a cleaning tape and running that through once a month. they are usually good for about 50 uses, so like 3-4 years.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>90898878
They will have a few redundant load balancers in-front of those servers, and when a request is received its sent to one of those servers round-robin to be handled. When a server stops passing health checks, the load balancer will stop sending requests to it until it recovers.

You can have a cluster of 3 pcs working on lots of smaller jobs, but one large serial task generally can't be split between several processors.

>>90899500
>over a local network.
yeah that's exactly what I said
>is only really useful on local networks
once you leave the local network, the delay between the host and the thing that renders the host (the client) becomes so great that trying to render even opening the start menu can take upwards of 30 seconds. this is because all rendering done is software rendering, and a good chunk of it is done on the client while connected to the session - if both your host and your client have great internet speeds, it's not that bad, but if not...
I frequently find myself having to disconnect to let the host render a menu, and then reconnect because the 15 seconds of time that takes is genuinely faster than waiting for the menus to render while connected.
>and is vastly superior to VNC
how so anyway? I've found VNC to have much higher bitrates and be overall much clearer than RDP, even on RDP's highest quality settings. The only thing VNC doesn't really do is allow captive cursors in 3d applications, although I'm sure some clients have ways to enable that.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90900324
>this much is true, because it's compressed video
Is it compressed video, as in it's actually using a video codec? I was under the impression VNC did not do this, which is exactly why it's slow. Actual streaming solutions which send a real video stream usually work much better, but require higher bandwidth to do it at good quality. I was under the impression solutions like VNC send chunks of image when they change and any compression applied is only rudimentary, at most to the content being sent and not in an actual video stream.
>Again it comes back to the software rendering happening on the client side.
You keep mentioning this as a downside, but I don't see exactly how or why. It's probably going to take less data to tell the client "draw a grey rectangle of a particular size at coords x,y" than it would to render the rectangle locally, then capture the image and send the entire modified area over the network. This seems like an entirely reasonable way of doing things if the goal is 2D desktop work, with the disadvantage that it's obviously not tenable for high performance 3D.

I have never seen this sort of delay that you're experiencing with RDP. I even connected to one of my VMs from my phone over cellular (4G) and it was fine. There's a perceptible delay (I would guess it's in the ~250ms range, well under 1s anyway) so it's not particularly responsive but the actual drawing happens quickly even over such a shitty connection.

>Real shame NVIDIA is killing their streaming platform
Are they actually killing it or just removing it from Shield TV on Android? I don't remember reading anything about the functionality being taken out on the PC side.
>steam remoteplay as an alternative, which is objectively terrible.
Works fairly well in my experience, but it has the typical problems of Valve software of not being particularly polished and as far as I'm aware it does software capture + hardware encode only, which hurts its performance at high resolution.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90898924
No SMR drives and ZFS doesn't mix well. For one thing lord help you if you ever do a drive replacement. The resliver time takes ages compared to a normal drive. For another due to how the drive is you'll get random CHKSUM errors tossed at you during scrubs. SMART can say "drive healthy" and you'll still get them at random times. And yes swapping out the cable (if you can) does little good.Still happens. But for all it's quirks the drives do the job. Just you have to clear out the errors and keep backups just in case (which you should do anyway). If I'd have to do it again I'd go with another brand. Note: CHKSUM errors aren't bad in an of themselves long as redundancy exists (Raid Z2 at minimum). Thing you have to watch for is read and write errors. I bought these drives in 2019. 6x of them. Only replaced one, rest are going good. I didn't know they were SMR till it was to late.

The Switch emulator can natively pass on CPU instructions to the M1 without modification. The GPU is emulated. The Switch has by far the biggest game library of actually decent games at the moment.

Once the Switch 2 hits and it has around PS4 performance you can bet your ass every studio is porting their Gen 8 games (there are no Gen 9 games anyway) to it. Which will basically hand them to M1 Mac users on a silver platter.

Worse than that is that the younger generations are basically exclusively mobile gamers (phones or tablets) so gradually you'll notice the industry will develop grander and more fully fledged serious games on mobile platforms, this is basically where Apple offers the only good hardware. >>90900954
to an extent you're not wrong, but by far the biggest problem with beginner pianists, especially self taught ones, is that they never properly learn how to approach playing the piano in a truly relaxed and "tense-free" manner, which I'd argue is the single most important thing for a beginner to learn from day 1. people that start learning how to properly leverage their entire playing apparatus (upper body, upper arms, lower arms, wrist, fingers) and begin managing tension from day 1 learn much much faster. the problem is learning the bio-mechanics of your body can be boring and tedious at first if all you wanna do is make pretty sounds. the meme channels start and end with "curve your hand like you're holding a ball" which is horrendously simplistic but is all your typical low attention span retard is willing to do which is why these channels do so well. obviously some of the techniques will be presented in the context of difficult pieces but it's easy for beginners to pick up some good habits since they explain the techniques well.

>>90902266
Guess it's different there. But, keep in mind MIDI has been around since the 80s, so even something from like the 90s, if it's solid and high quality, will probably have MIDI capabilities so even though the sound is shit you can just hook it up to a computer and use something like Pianoteq. What matters is the keyboard itself, and that it's weighted, literally everything else is fixable. Yamaha Clavinovas are probably the most common where you'll still find ancient ones, but also Casio, Kawai, Korg, and Roland, at least, have all made high quality digital pianos or other keyboard instruments for decades. I guess, if the price is low enough, don't be afraid to get something that like 10-20 years old, so long as the keys themselves function. Of course I wouldn't pay anywhere near the price of a brand new modern one, like some of the idiots selling used gear are asking.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
When engineers report that switching to Vim has massively improved their productivity, I can't help but think that the way they work must be very, very different from my own.
When I "program", 95% of what I do is read documentation and other technical resources, conceptualize what I want to happen, and construct the corresponding logic flow, while trying to anticipate potential problems and corner cases. In other words, most of what I do doesn't involve touching the keyboard at all.

If Vim magically tripled the speed at which I'm able to edit text, I doubt it would have a noticeable impact on my overall productivity. In fact, even if you gave me a brain-computer interface that allowed me to manipulate text at the speed of thought, it wouldn't matter much. I touch-type at around 70 WPM, which is very average, but if I two-finger typed at 15 WPM instead I would still be able to produce exactly as much code as I do today.

Simply put, text manipulation is not at all a productivity bottleneck for me. I need much more time for thinking about code than I need for writing it.

Is this really unusual? How do people operate for whom Vim gives a productivity boost? Does code just flow from their brains into their fingers? I don't get it.

You are kind of correct, and that's the main reason vim (more accurately, modal editing) is just in the realm of very useful and well-liked instead of absolutely undisputed de facto standard.
For me at least the main bonus isn't in literal speed, but more abstract than that, in shortening the gap between thinking and the code being on the screen.

It's a little difficult to describe, but it's like something about the act of moving the mouse around and moving my hands around and clicking text feels more effortful and slower than the constant brain engagement of vim navigation. There's less space for the brain to wander, less 'lag' between thinking and doing. I just feel like I get into a flow state much easier when using vim.
If I had to place a bet I'd guess using modal commands to navigate and edit involves a different stretch of the brain than scroll and click.

posts.com:
>>90892064
I like vim, and I use vim keybindings everywhere because they're ergonomic & handy to use for navigation within the context of doing something keyboard based. However, I don't entirely buy the argument that vim is necessarily always more efficient, or totally breaks down the "mind/computer interface" as some people like to put it. For some tasks, perhaps, but I often times find that using the mouse is the more direct operation with less cognitive overhead. I spent a long time trying to go keyboard-only for my entire desktop, and I found it really constraining and inefficient for some tasks.

In truth, I've found that I'm very efficient using a combination of vim keybindings and the mouse. If I'm already typing out some code, I'd prefer to just keep my hands on the keyboard, especially if I'm navigating within the range of a few lines. However, if I'm browsing through my code and making changes here and there, I find that it's less clunky to just scroll with the mouse wheel and click directly where I need to go with the mouse, rather than typing "14j, wwwww" or "/foo, nnnn". A nice thing is that a lot of useful vim commands can be done entirely with your left hand (dd, cw, C, ea, and so on), so I can use the mouse for broad movements and my left hand to perform some kind of operation. In fact, I've based a lot of my desktop workflow around that idea, and it works really nicely.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90892064
I used Vim as my primary editor for over 4 years and I came to the conclusion that Vi-style keybindings (and modal editing in general) are just not for me.

Most of the time, I perform short bursts of insertions alternated with short bursts of non-insertion commands, and that is more efficient (albeit arguably less ergonomic) with non-modal keybindings. Also, Vim has rather poor mouse support, even if you use the GVim frontend. Because yes, the mouse is very useful for editing text and deliberately restricting yourself by not using it is silly.

If you like Vim, by all means keep using it, but don't pretend your preferences are universal. The best tool for the job is often the one you're most comfortable with.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
The other LORA rentry anon here.
Good news everyone!
Kinda.
I've finished this LORA (dreambooth style) with the "--color-aug" and "--flip-aug" arguments.
The performance hit seems worth it, the outputs so far have been of higher general quality but it seems it lost some detail accuracy, it's losing the jigglypuff curl and dress details more often, but getting the feather hairband more consistently, need to see more outputs.
Might be better at higher epochs. Still seems to be a way to enhance a poor image set, I will give it a test with more epochs and see how it compares.
Somehow this method really made the glitter gimmick stuff pop a lot more, too.

It added like 5 more minutes for 1800 steps (from 45:10 to 50:50), most of the time difference came from reading images from disk as it went, which on linux is generally fast on repeat opens, so it might take a bit longer on windows. Of course will take longer with more images, as well.
Remember that to use the aug parameters you must disable caching latents (the script will let you know though).

I'm starting to feel the initial numbers for a formula to figure out the ideal network dimensions and total epochs for a given result, but I'm not the best mathematician. So I'll figure it out by trial and error instead.

Daily reminder:
>The Luddites were a secret oath-based organisation[1] of English textile workers in the 19th century who formed a radical faction which destroyed textile machinery. The group is believed to have taken its name from Ned Ludd, a legendary weaver supposedly from Anstey, near Leicester. They protested against manufacturers who used machines in what they called "a fraudulent and deceitful manner" to get around standard labour practices.[2] Luddites feared that the time spent learning the skills of their craft would go to waste, as machines would replace their role in the industry.[3]

>Many Luddites were owners of workshops that had closed because factories could sell the same products for less. But when workshop owners set out to find a job at a factory, it was very hard to find one because producing things in factories required fewer workers than producing those same things in a workshop. This left many people unemployed and angry.[4]

>The Luddite movement began in Nottingham in England and culminated in a region-wide rebellion that lasted from 1811 to 1816.[5] Mill and factory owners took to shooting protesters and eventually the movement was suppressed with legal and military force, which included execution and penal transportation of accused and convicted Luddites.[6]

You are welcome! I'm going to run it again for 14 epochs, should take one hour and 10 minutes. If that fixes the jigglypuff curl I'll call it the best one so far.

As a reminder that one is dreambooth style (17 reg images), 160 net dim, 12 epochs, 1e-4 learning rate, 5e-5 learning rate for text encoder.
Most images are chibi or loli-looking except for a couple (the official art has a less chibi one used in the game's VS screens, it might be where it's getting the large booba from since she does have a noticeable bust there, heh), so it's a good measure of how strong the source art influences style over details.

Could have moved to a more popular character for testing but this one has ideal conditions to measure if ANYTHING improves the results.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90897437
>I have no idea how to add "texture" that's more than just retriggering different parts of the break.
Do you mean like when you get a time-streatched amen snare?

There's a couple of different ways to do it. A somewhat dirty way to do it is by interpolating the slice command on a fast ticked pattern. This is how you would have done it in an old school tracker. Other things you could do is use a retrigger command. In FT2 it was either R00 or E90, not sure what it is in Renoise. This would give a more high pitched glitch-y noise. A third old-school way would have been to edit the samples into multiple chunks and then have them looped with a very short loop. Lastly for something more modern, Renoise has it's repeater effect that you can use.

>Also, how do I do the dnb staple of retriggered sample getting louder with every hit?
That's pretty easy, you could just insert the desired value in the volume column. So for every snare hit in a sequence would be raised a value or so.

>>90907245
Open source software is neither secure or private just because it is open. FOSS projects often lack necessary funding for development, maintaince and security audits, while on the other hand proprietary software usually comes with a price tag , which allows the owners to pay the developers and pentesters (speaking of that, black box audits are also a thing).

The thing with "its open source so anyone can audit it" is a clever idea that would work in abstract world, but practically speaking it doesnt work at all. Unless you actually read the code yourself and compile everything from source, you have no idea whats really going on, and this is pretty much impossible to do if we are talking about so huge projects like linux kernel or chromium engine, consisting of millions of lines of code.There is nothing that stops kernel(.)org admins or developers of individual distrubutions from backdooring your kernel as well.

baloo is a file indexer, so if it crashes then some programs will either not be aware of changes to your files until you restart balloo, or theyll switch to baloo-less operation with less instant refreshing (may require program restart or pressing a rescan button for files). i dont believe baloo is absolutely necessary so if there isnt an upstream fix in the works or an easy workaround, you might just want to turn baloo off. you should report the bug though so it can get fixed.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>90878319
EQ is a shotgun, not a sniper rifle. You're getting an approximation of what you're aiming at with your EQ parameters. You're also limited by the capability of the driver and it's stock physical configuration (diaphragm, impedance, airflow, filters, etc). Your IEM also has it's own tonality/timbre, which differs.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90878319
unit variation, measurement variation, differences between your ears/hearing and the measurement rig... it could be basically anything. if you grab someone else's graph of someone else's example of the same model and assume that you can make adjustments with PEQ based on it you are going to be wildly, violently wrong almost all of the time.

>>90878473
>Your IEM also has it's own tonality/timbre, which differs.
Tonality is entirely just frequency response. There are indeed circumstances where the driver cannot physically produce a certain pressure wave but most of the time when something doesn't sound as it should it's just because the measurement fed to AutoEQ isn't specific to that IEM or your ears so garbage in = garbage out. The solution is to stop trying to ripoff the sound signature of other IEMs and just tune by ear, if the end result doesn't sound better than literally all stock IEMs in existence you suck.

EQ is mandatory, not using it is cope.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90898593
Happy to try and help advise, many of us started with similar upgrade paths. FYI I do test my IEMs with music and FPS game (Rainbow Six Siege)
1) Tripowin x HBB Olina SE: Top of the line dynamic driver. Will offer speedy sound with great layering/separation ability. Slightly above average videogame audio performance. The bass is on the lighter side, but not in any distracting way, still present and natural.
2) A planar magnetic IEM. For my money, Shuoer S12 Pro, Tangzu Zetian Wu (Heyday optional), or Tinhifi P1 MAX are good choices at affordable prices. Speaking as owner of S12 Pro and P1 MAX, they have great videogame audio tracking performance. Offer a wide soundstage and pinpoint sound tracking ability in front, behind, L/R, above and below in ways that many cheaper dynamic drivers and middle-tier hybrid IEMs struggle to provide. Why placed below Olina SE? I firmly believe that planars do not sound optimal with lower-end dongles/DACs. Only with better gear like a Dawn/Space via balanced do they sound their best, so this is a qualifying factor.
3) QKZ x HBB with EQ. Not a joke, this $20 model performs admirably in videogames, offering a good soundstage where you can track sounds accurately. It's weakness is in the tuning when you desire cleaner mids, as it has lots of bass and midbloat. This can be EQ'd out, which reveals that the driver is pretty well performing across the board.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90899169
>>90899713
Been enjoying the music you posted, lovely. First track specifically a few differences between Letshuoer S12 Pro and Tinhifi P1 MAX. I am not music expert so please excuse if I get instrument class wrong.

I prefer the way brass/wind and string instruments sound on P1 MAX because they retain a more natural timbre. There is a slight honky/plastic-y timbre in the treble of S12 Pro. Also at higher frequency, there is some sharpness with the S12 Pro that I do not feel with the P1 MAX. Difference of individual hearing/ears, this "sharpness" can maybe equate to "bright, detailed" for you. To reiterate, not crazy sibilant, but some extra energy in the upper frequencies with S12 Pro. You mention KZ ZSN, S12 Pro is more refined than that.

S12 Pro wins bass and drums. A more vibrant, engaging thump especially 3:30-4:30 when listening with the S12 Pro. Same applies to bass throughout rest of song, S12 Pro is deeper reaching, more full-bodied bass. The bass plays well in P1 MAX, but not to a similar level of engagement and oomph.

Both sets deliver nicely separated L/R imaging, distinct instrument separation and layering. Never encounter "cloudy, obscured, messy" sensation. All sounds play clean and distinct.

Tough to definitively rec one set based on this track listening. To further complicate your decision (haha sorry), consider the Tangzu Zetian Wu (and Heyday edition) and it will have it's own little quirks, pros and cons. The S12 Pro and Heyday specifically come with swappable cables so you are ready right away to listen via 2.5/3.5/4.4mm connection if you do get a new DAC with balanced connection. Ordering from Amazon is a nice way to try a set and if you really have issues with it, returning is easier than with other retailers. Hope that helps a little

posts.name: Anonymous

>>90906893
I think most of the spatial qualities resulting from crosstalk are are only applicable to loudspeakers at a distance since humans are exceptionally sensitive to the delay of a sound reaching one ear vs the other because we use it for imaging in real life. Which is to say speakers literally have a soundstage that localizes outside the head regardless of directionality and that is very different from the FR and HRTF combination that may occasionally create a similar feeling when listening to certain parts of stereo recordings with headphones or IEMs but is by no means universal. I don't think blending the channels together would do much by itself.

Anyway I'm not accusing you of anything but the brain is a funny thing and I'm not sure your perception of the reduced treble and improved spatiality of your new amp would be apparent in a blind test, especially if the distortion was matched.

i was going to link this article but unfortunately it is now pay-walled:
https://quillette.com/2015/12/01/why-parenting-may-not-matter-and-why-most-social-science-research-is-probably-wrong/

the tl;dr is that the positive outcomes associated with what people consider "good parenting" is genetically confounded. e.g. intelligent, well-behaved parents have kids that are intelligent and well-behaved because they inherit their genes. those kids would grow up to be intelligent and well-behaved regardless of the upbringing. this is very unintuitive to most people because most people are very creative and make up elaborate stories about their life where they attribute key characteristics of themselves to certain features or moments in their childhood.

i used to do that too until i realized i was just bullshitting myself and basically making shit up that "seemed" true to me. for example i attributed my anxiety to an event in school. in reality i was inevitably going to be an anxious person because i inherited it from my dad - and i didn't even grow up around him. that moment in school was just an environment in which i first became aware of my anxiety, but it didn't cause it like i used to think. people do this with fetishes too, where they confuse a moment where they first realized they liked something, with that moment causing their liking of of that something.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
14 epochs out of the oven.
This test involved using the "aug" arguments (--color_aug and --flip_aug) to train.

It's still not doing the jigglypuff curl consistently but the outputs seem to have higher quality and contrast overall, it's also remembering the dress has a different color at the sleeves and rim of the skirt more often.

Note that I've been posting "raw" gens (no img2img, inpainting or high res fix) for all these samples.

So yeah using those args apparently increases quality but requires more training to get details. Tempted to do 16 epochs now. These aug arguments might be worth the extra training time for characters with poor artwork.

I'm going to make another test but replacing the reg images so I can see how they affect things a bit better.

posts.com:
>>90903515
Yeah it was mostly official art and the least crusty fanart I could find. Neither is great, but the AI is doing a great job at distilling the details.
If I can get that side curl more than half the gens I'll call it an absolute victory. (I think she's supposed to only have it on one side)

This one really needed the investigation too. The regular LORA training only really worked when prompting for watercolors and while it had good fidelity the training images brought the results down considerably, specially at higher network dimensions.

The Dreambooth style helped make it more flexible, and the augs helped bring the quality up at the cost of more training steps. It's still below the hour mark so it's manageable.

I'll now test with repeats instead of epochs and see if it makes any difference at the same number of steps.

posts.com:
OK, I recommended the Pentel Sign Pen last thread, but am very disappointed that it's not waterpoof ink. Great pen, trash ink. But there are better options available like Tombow Fudenosuke which has permanent ink and a similar flex tip.
If you've bought a Pentel Sign Pen I highly recommend searching online for how to refill a fineliner to fill it with proper ink like Rotring ink. A drop or two would suffice in making the sign pen permanent even if the shitty ink washes off, as well as the benefit of refilling it until the tip wears out.
On the upside the tip is said to be very long lasting.

>>90897665
Permanent ink, really fine lines, lack of bleeding/smearing. Only a sakura micron or something like it can provide these features. They were originally designed for engineers after all. Everything else is just snobbery, you get nothing, you just spend more on a pen. If you have a weak wrist you may notice more comfort and smoothness.

I have 4 fountain pens, mostly gifts, and they are all princesses that produce less legible results on checks (the only thing you NEED pens for) than a sakura micron because the best possible ink still bleeds and spreads out on that thin paper.

I use the pen that is present, or if it is important I fill it out using a sakura micron PN so I can be assured it won't get fucked up and smeared and can't be washed out by some smug fuck with a bottle of acetone.

>>90904884
>Ctrl+A
>right click
>click
playFolder(){
    folder="${1:-.}"
    find "$folder" -type f -regextype egrep -iregex ".*\.(ape|[af]lac|m(4a|p3)|o(gg|pus)|wav)" | sort -z | xargs mpv --no-audio-display
}

Add that to ~/.bashrc, run 
source ~/.bashrc
to apply, and either call the folder as an argument or cd into the folder before running.

Got a key you don't use? Make it your music player with xbindkeys.
"mpc toggle"
  Mod2 + XF86Calculator
"mpc next"
  Control+Mod2 + XF86Calculator
"mpc prev"
  Shift+Control+Mod2 + XF86Calculator
"mpc volume +5"
  Control+Mod2 + XF86AudioRaiseVolume
"mpc volume -5"
  Control+Mod2 + XF86AudioLowerVolume

Hobbyist programmers aren't normally concerned with reinventing the wheel, you aren't trying to innovate over existing technology you're having fun and upskilling

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
It's a really bad idea for several reasons. The biggest is underestimating how much time you need to finish a decent game, much less an engine. You were probably thinking of making one at some point, right? Well take that estimate and multiply it by 50. Yes, no exaggeration, it's simply that big of a project. And estimating the complexity of an engine is 10 times worse. Factor in limited motivation and you're really only left with 2 realistic choices: never making a game ever or using all the shortcuts you can. Yes, you're probably imagining how easy it is to write a 20 liner to render an image or a 40 liner for displaying a 3d model in opengl and thinking "durrr it can't be THAT bad". But it is. It's hard to explain. You don't think it be like that but it do. Another reason is underestimating how fast modern hardware is. On one hand, you probably share the notion that modern software is too bloated and can be done better. But you're again forced to make a choice here: spending years learning to optimize your shit and probably lose interest in the whole thing thus, again, never making anything, or making SOMETHING that actually works at full speed on 95% machines anyway, within a reasonable time frame. One more is underestimating how flexible modern game engines are. You can really do any game you want in them. You just need to learn if you can't see that.
Basically, it's an issue of making actually realistic choices that have actually good odds of coming true. Obviously, in a perfect world, you would make everything from scratch, and your ebin multiplayer open world harvest moon/pokemon roguelike with voxel graphics and procedural everything would run on a toaster and you'd be crowned king of videogames. But given that making GOOD games requires you to have not only proficiency in programming (however small) but also a means to make assets, your ability to do so from scratch is nil since you're only human, with limited time, ability and motivation.

>Why does everyone say not to make your own game engine?
The arguments on both sides are usually retarded. The nodevs in favor of using engines say "don't reinvent the wheel," and the nodevs on the other side play internet tough guy that anything other than hand-crafted assembler means you aren't a real programmer.

Reality is different for every case. There are pros and cons of each approach as well as various degrees in between.

>wouldn't it make more sense for me to create my own engine?
You need to handle graphics, sound, I/O, and game state. You probably want to use libraries for at least the first three. Maybe you want also libraries for mechanics like physics and collision detection. You need tools for creating assets and content.

Something like Unity tries to be an all-in-one package for everyone, including teams that have both experienced programmers and artists and designers more accustomed to traditional gui tools like photoshop and blender. Godot is like a budget Unity. But you're going to inherit a lot of complexity that is very likely to slow you down once you get past the first few days of spawning a skeleton project and you have to coerce your ideas into the features provided by the engine.

>Cakez
You're speaking as if he's going to go through the same process again for his next game. What these discussions usually neglect to consider is that time spent on the initial setup/learning/architecture is not the same at all as the bulk of the game development time.

Most kinds of games take at least a few years to make no matter what tool you use, in that grand scheme of things the time spent on the engine isn't that big at all. And once you've made an engine, you can easily re-use parts of it so the time spent on the engine is significantly lower than the first time around. From what I understand Cakez learned to make and made his own Vulkan renderer, it seems tedious and unnecessary but he won't have to go through that process all over again for his next game. He may modify or improve it but the work is mostly one-off and already done.

Having your own engine can in some cases speed up development because you're far more familiar with all the different parts and can more easily rewrite any part of it. Arguably learning to make an engine mandates that you get good at programming, which also makes you progress faster.
