Great post. A big question for a new dev is whether you will learn more by getting up and running quickly with an engine, or starting from scratch. It's going to take a long time either way. Some people are more likely to give up or get lost if they spend too much time on foundations.
They might spend weeks building basic components with no real vision of how to even get a full game working. Others will get frustrated and bored using a game engine, when they hit a wall where they have some problem and progress gets stalled entirely while they comb through reams of docs and discussions and asset store tools pages trying to find the best solution to a specific and maybe uncommon problem. Then the demoralizing process of choosing between 2-3 suboptimal solutions and adapting your game design to better fit the expectations of premade tools.

>>90887575
What people mean when they say this is you will almost always be able to make your game much faster if you go with an off-the-shelf engine.
>Wouldn't this make me an all around better programmer?
Yeah it probably would. It would also teach you a lot about graphics, sound, input, collision detection, scene management and so on. If your goal is to learn, or if you are doing it for fun, then go for it.
Godot makes it easy to have a somewhat hybrid approach. Most of the vanilla engine features are implemented in module directories which can simply be deleted from the source tree to strip the engine of features you don't care about (VR, file format support, gdscript, etc) and you can implement your own modules however you need. This is great if you want a jumping off point to implement specific low level features but don't want to deal with the really tedious boilerplate stuff like input handling or window management.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>90900644
>You find bugs in your engine by using it to make your game
This is why in-house engines designed to make a specific games are a nightmare to use elsewhere. E.g. the source engine is full of hacky workarounds for specific Valve titles in engine code. Frostbite has a huge reputation for being a pain in the ass because DICE develops it for their style of games, then EA forces it's other subsidiaries to use it (see Mass Effect Andromeda).
General purpose engines don't have this problem because they need to accommodate a huge amount of games simultaneously, so features are usually introduced in a way that isn't tailored to any specific game - that's the game code's responsibility.
General purpose engines tend to be rigorously documented as well, so it's easy to figure out if a function's behaviour meets the spec.

I'm not saying they did not resist. Just that I don't see the benefit of using them.
If you really need private and secure email communication, then use something like Elude over Tor, self-hosting between two parties that know they are doing, or other options.
Better yet, if you have something you just need to keep private, don't use emails in the first place.

But for most people what's the point of going for RiseUp over Posteo, Tutanota, Protonmail or some other relatively "private" email provider?
Even if you're to assume government agencies see all your communication from aforementioned providers, what is the problem here?
They don't care about your email to confirm a new Steam account creation, nor do they care that you bought a book from an online store.
On the other hand, companies like Google do care about that as the data about you is used for advertising, profiling for ad targeting etc.
Mind you, I'm NOT saying them knowing about that is in any way OK. Preferably, they should know nothing about my email communication. But given how insecure emails inherently are, most people being unwilling and unable to self-host, reliance on 3rd parties providers will never not be a privacy and security vulnerability, then you have to be a realist about it and realize that your threat model for emails shouldn't care about government agencies unless you're doing something that warrants such protection.
Therefore, the "privacy" focused email providers are fine for 99.9% of people.

I just don't see the way to keep all your email communication safe and private without it ever possibly getting exposed. The second you send an email, you can't consider the data you send to be private anymore, unless you're using encryption and communicating with someone who ensures the email's deletion after their read it.

>>90900718
How does that prevent the data from being potentially leaked or accessed by someone else, anon?

Let's say you want to communicate with any entity (bank, car dealership, school etc.) securely and privately.
You literally can't do that as they most often don't offer an option to use encryption.
But let's say they do and you encrypt your communication with OpenPGP/GPG/whatever encryption.
That still doesn't protect you if they get hacked, are forced to hand over the data/your emails, or the emails are processed by some system for whatever reason.
The only way to communicate securely and privately is if you used encryption for all your email communication and you can somehow ensure the delivered emails never get leaked/given to the authorities.
Zero access encryption solves only the problem of the data at rest, not the issue that the receiver of your emails won't hand over their emails or their access gets compromised.

>I don't know how long you've been on /g/
The sad state of affairs is that a lot of security/privacy stuff is really convoluted with layers of complexity involving literally everything, such as your HW, boot, OS, SW, services, ports, networking, FWs and a fuck ton of more.
It takes an ungodly amount of knowledge and experience to be able to handle all those aspects and even more to actively mitigate all potential attack vectors and what not.
Which is why I think the whole topic of security/privacy is mostly about compromises, be it in solutions or their knowledge/expertise.
Not only that, but you also have the problems of conflicting opinions, misunderstandings, bad actors spreading disinformation and more, which makes it harder to create proper solution to all the problems, and that's without taking into account human ignorance and people having varying needs and setups to which the solutions need to adapt.
The best a person can do is to do what they realistically can do to protect themselves and mitigate everything they can while slowly learning more.
But I do think that a lot of people overthinks a lot of stuff and has a mindset that anything but complete, perfect privacy solution and security is not good enough, which is counter-productive because such things is mostly impossible really and makes discussions only harder as it makes people focus on trying to find perfect solutions instead of looking for something that is "good enough".
But anyhow, I think you're okay, anon. Keep up the good work. I'm in the same boat as you really.

functional package manager

scripts in execline
mksh as sh

You can't buy a new machine that runs Windows XP well. There are now drivers available.
If you are serious about this, look into Laptops as late as 2015/2016 and check available drivers. The further back you go, the better your chances.
For relatively fast and modern browsing you can either use MyPal (https://github.com/Feodor2/Mypal68) or a chinked version of Chrome 86 (https://msfn.org/board/topic/182876-360-extreme-explorer-modified-version/). It's probably best to have both available.
Also, check out https://legacyupdate.net/ for fixing root certificates, activation and automatic updates.

This works for me as a daily driver unironically.

>>90887542
1.1gbps on Fast.com means nothing, almost assuredly testing error.

I've seen 1.2gbps+ from Fast.com using a 1gbps ethernet NIC, which is physically impossible to achieve.

With TCP/IP packet overhead of 5.5% the fastest you can EVER achieve over a 1gbps ethernet NIC is ~945mbps. Anything faster is just a rounding error or some other testing error.

>>90892964
>With TCP/IP packet overhead of 5.5% the fastest you can EVER achieve over a 1gbps ethernet NIC is ~945mbps.
Yup, unless you change to use jumbo frames or something which no ISP would support anyway for WAN traffic unless you had an SLA and the ISP allowed their network to be configured for the larger frame size.
But realistically, that'll almost never happen, so the fastest you''ll ever get for residential 1gbps over ethernet, is 945mbps.

>>90903578
if you're using ethernet, you're probably using a 1gbps NIC

if you're using wifi, you probably don't have enough spatial streams for more than 1gbps, or if you do the RF conditions prohibit reaching the highest speeds regularly.


If you're using ethernet though, you need to be using 2.5gbps NICs or better to be capable of 1.2gbps speeds, and if you have a network switch or something between you and the router you need that to be 2.5+gbps capable as well.
